text: you
there were a hundred and twenty six
public school buildings in New Orleans
when Hurricane Katrina hit more than
half of them sustained serious damage in
the flood now almost three years later
many of the city's schools have been
rehabilitated and reopened and
construction is underway on a handful of
new school buildings but there are other
schools all across New Orleans that
aren't ever coming back this is Alfred
lawless high school in the Lower Ninth
Ward one of the casualties of Katrina
after the storm it was completely filled
with water flooded to the ceiling
covered to a depth of 15 or 20 feet just
from the damage alone it was hard to
imagine that lawless could be reopened
but there was another problem too there
was no one left in the neighborhood to
go to school there the blocks around
lawless which were once full of houses
and people are now mostly depopulated
school officials have had to make
difficult choices all over New Orleans
about which schools to restore and which
ones to abandon at lawless there were a
few protests early on by neighborhood
residents who wanted to save the school
but they didn't really get anywhere and
in June lawless was finally torn down
this spring just a few weeks before the
bulldozers moved in I got a tour of the
